metadata./Title: Conservative surgical repair of placenta increta invading into uterine septum: case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background The prevalence of placenta accreta spectrum is on the rise, primarily as a consequence of an increasing 
number of Cesarean sections. Nevertheless, uterine anomalies, particularly uterine septum, pose a notable risk factor 
for its occurrence. While there are limited case reports documenting the association between uterine septum and placenta adherence, most of these cases have been linked to prior hysteroscopic treatment of the septum. Notably, this 
case represents the first-reported instance in which a uterine septum was preoperatively diagnosed in association 
with placenta increta adherent to it, and subsequently managed conservatively.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 30-year-old pregnant Egyptian female patient, who had undergone two previous cesarean 
sections, was diagnosed with placenta increta and had an incomplete uterine septum. She was admitted to Elshatby 
University Hospital in December 2021. During her surgery, it was found that the placenta was adherent to right 
lower aspect of the septum, as well as the right anterior, lateral, and posterior uterine walls. A conservative surgical approach was scheduled and successfully performed, and 3 months later, an ultrasound examination revealed 
that the uterus had returned to its normal size, with no evidence of isthmocele or synechiae. The only abnormality 
noted was the presence of the septum.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Ultrasound plays a crucial role in diagnosing placenta accreta and identifying any additional uter ine abnormalities that may guide the planning of conservative treatment. Uterine septum represents a risk factor 
for placental adherence, as the placenta can indeed become adherent to it. Muscle defects may become apparent 
following placental separation and can often be effectively managed through the use of running sutures, obviating 
the need for resection of the affected portion.

Background
The prevalence of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) from 
1982 to 2018 has been estimated to be approximately 1 in 
10,000 pregnancies. It is important to note that maternal 
mortality associated with PAS has been reported to be as 
high as 7% of cases [1]. Several probable risk factors have 
been identified, including Cesarean section and uterine 
metroplasty [2].Open Access

A retrospective study has indicated that uterine anom alies can elevate the risk of abnormal implantation in the 
lower uterine segment. This is attributed to the abnormal 
uterine cavity configuration, which in turn increases the 
likelihood of placental adherence, particularly in cases 
with a history of previous Cesarean sections [3].
Placental increta infiltrating both a uterine septum and 
uterine walls indeed appears to be unique and represents 
the first-reported instance in the literature.
It is important to note that while planned Cesarean hys terectomy with a supraplacental uterine incision is con sidered the most widely accepted management approach 
for PAS, conservative treatments have been explored and 
successfully performed. These
sections.Methods:
methods typically involve 
resection of the affected anterior segment or application 
of compression sutures [4, 5]. However, there is limited 
documentation of conservative anatomical repair spe cifically for posterior wall, lateral wall, or uterine septum 
invasion in the existing literature.
The objective of this case report is to explore a surgical 
conservative technique that can be beneficial in manag ing placental adherence to the posterior and lateral uter ine walls. Furthermore, it is important to emphasize the 
placenta’s capacity to penetrate a uterine septum, which 
can be effectively separated and managed conservatively.
Case presentation
The patient had been diagnosed with increta and was 
scheduled for elective conservative surgery in Decem ber 2021 at Elshatby University Hospital in Alexandria, 
a tertiary care facility that handles approximately 13,000 
deliveries per year.
A 30-year-old pregnant female patient from Egypt was 
referred to our hospital from a private clinic, gravida 6, 
para 4, with a history of one previous miscarriage in the 
first trimester. The patient had undergone two previous 
Cesarean sections without complications, and her most 
recent pregnancy occurred 6 years ago. She has two liv ing female children and has experienced two previous 
neonatal deaths due to chromosomal anomalies. At the 
time of assessment, she was 36 weeks gestational. The 
patient has no known underlying medical conditions or 
history of prior surgeries. She did not report any episodes 
of vaginal bleeding or abdominal pain during this preg nancy. It is worth noting that in her previous first Cesar ean section, a uterine septum was accidentally identified; 
however, her previous obstetricians determined that sep tum removal was unnecessary as her delivery resulted in 
full-term baby.
A transvaginal and transabdominal ultrasound and 
Doppler were done; baby was small for gestational age 
at 32 weeks with a weight of 1900 gm, and the umbili cal artery Doppler revealed a high systolic/diastolic ratio of 3.68. Placenta previa was noted, with increta affect ing the anterior and right posterior walls according to 
Cali et  al. and Pagani et  al., with ultrasound classifica tion (loss of the clear zone, myometrium thickness less 
than 1 mm, placental bulge, and non-interrupted bladder 
and uterine serosa) accompanied by some bridging ves sels over the uterine serosa (Fig.  1) [6, 7]. Uterine septum 
was observed, reaching internal OS, and the placenta was 
adherent to its lower right aspect (Fig.  2). Both placenta 
and baby were positioned on the right aspect of the sep tum, causing the septum to be displaced to the left.
Her hemoglobin level was 12.5 gm/dl and her hema tocrit was measured at 35.7% at 24 hours prior to the 
operation. Additionally, her coagulation profile, as well as 
liver and kidney functions, were within normal ranges.
The patient declined a hysterectomy due to her young 
age and the potential impacts on her sexual life and blad der function due to the radicality of the surgery and the 
necessary to do a subplacental hysterectomy (modified 
type 2 radical hysterectomy), which might injure the 
nerve supply to the bladder and vagina [8]. Consequently, 
informed consent was obtained, and she agreed to par ticipate in the clinical trial evaluating the outcomes of 
uterine conservation following the closure of myome trium defects resulting from manual placental separation 
in patients diagnosed with placenta accreta spectrum 
(PAS). The clinical trial had received approval from both 
the board committee and the ethical committee of Alex andria Medical Faculty.
The surgery was carried out 1 week later (at 37 gesta tional weeks) with the aim of minimizing the likelihood 
of neonatal intensive care unit admission, ensuring that it 
did not pose additional risks to the mother and the baby. 
The procedure was performed by a multidisciplinary 
team comprising consultant obstetricians, a consultant 
anesthesiologist, and an on-call urologist, and involved 
the manual removal of the placenta followed by the clo sure of the revealed myometrium defects to halt the 
bleeding from the placenta bed by running sutures.
Intraoperatively, a wide transverse skin incision was 
made. Upon reaching the uterus, placenta increta was 
diagnosed in accordance with the International Fed eration of Obstetrics and Gynecology (FIGO) placenta 
accreta classification (Fig.  3). The bladder was found 
adherent to the uterus with some bridging vessels, and a 
placental bulge was evident.
The bladder was carefully dissected, and the bridging 
vessels were coagulated. A transverse uterine incision 
was made above the placenta followed by the delivery 
of the baby, uterotonics were administered, and then 
the placenta was separated from the uterine wall, start ing from nonadherent areas and then more adherent 
parts, including the uterine septum (Fig.  4). During the

procedure, myometrium defects were identified above 
the internal OS in the right aspect of septum, the right 
anterior wall, the right lateral wall, and right posterior 
wall. These defects were closed with running sutures 
while the septum itself was left in place (video). Through out the closure of the incisions, continuous monitoring 
of the cervix for patency was conducted. Subsequently, 
the uterus was closed in two layers and intraperitoneal 
drain was inserted. While closing the abdominal wall, the 
patient’s vital signs remained stable, with her blood pres sure at 120/72 mmHg, heart rate at 98 beats per minute, 
and a urine output throughout the operation of 150 ml. 
The estimated blood loss during the surgery was 1900 ml. 
In accordance with local protocol, the patient received 
two units of fresh frozen plasma; however, there was no 
need to commence packed red blood cells transfusion.
The patient was transferred to the intermediate care 
unit for a 12-hour period before being moved to the 
ward, and 6 hours after surgery, her hemoglobin level 
measured at 9.5 gm/dl, hematocrit at 29.7%, and platelet 
count at 171,000/ul. The patient remained in the hospital 
for a duration of 3 days.
Her menstrual cycle resumed 75 days after the opera tion, and 3 months later, a two-dimensional (2D) grayscale transvaginal ultrasound was performed, revealing 
an anteverted anteflexed uterus with dimensions measur ing 7.31 × 3.26 × 5.17 cm and an incomplete uterine sep tum. The thinnest anterior wall myometrium thickness 
measured 1.01 cm, while the posterior wall measured 
1.11 cm in sagittal thickness. No uterine wall defects or 
intrauterine adhesions were detected.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
A uterine septum is categorized as either complete or 
partial on the basis of its lower limit in relation to the 
cervix [9, 10]. Septate uteri can contribute to various 
pregnancy complications, including pregnancy loss, pre term labor, malpresentation, and small for gestational age 
baby. [9, 11, 12]
To the best of our knowledge, the existing literature has 
not previously described placental adherence to a nonre sected uterine septum.
It is worth noting that histological specimens of septa, 
after excision, have revealed the presence of muscular tis sue along with fibrous components [13, 14]. This raises 
the possibility that the placenta may exhibit an affin ity for the myometrium, potentially creeping toward it 
over a uterine septum. However, it is unlikely to invade 
its fibrous component. In this specific case, the placenta 
exhibited adherence to the right aspect of the septum 
without penetrating to the other side. Consequently, 
uterine septum could represent a potential site for pla cental adherence.

Various methods have been described for manag ing placenta accreta spectrum, including leaving the 
placenta in  situ (the expectant approach), removal of 
the invaded area, insertion of Bakri balloon, and com pression sutures such as the transverse B-lynch. These 
methods can be employed individually or in combi nation with or without the use of internal iliac artery 
occlusion. [5 ]
There is no universally standardized surgical method 
that can be uniformly applied to all patients with placen tal invasion. However, certain methods may be applied 
sequentially or omitted depending on the specific case 
[15–17]. Most of the existing methods have not described 
a technique suitable for managing invasion into the lat eral and posterior uterine walls or in cases involving 
a septum, as seen in this instance [5]. For example, the 
resection of the myometrium invaded by the placenta is 
one of the most used techniques. However, it becomes 
impractical when dealing with invasion into the posterior 
uterine wall or when the invasion encompasses the pos terior, lateral, and anterior walls simultaneously. In such 
situations, hysterectomy often becomes the only practical 
option.
One study suggested the application of running sutures 
around the internal OS to close the placental bed. These 
sutures are initiated from the lower edge at the inter nal cervical OS muscle and extend to the upper edge at 
the uterine serosa. While this technique is beneficial for 
repairing low posterior and lateral wall invasions, it may 
not be suitable for addressing high invasion sites or uter ine septum invasions [18].
After the separation of the placenta, the presence of 
muscle defects was observed, surrounded by normal 
myometrium, with distinct upper and lower edges. These 
defects can be sutured and closed without the need for 
compression sutures or internal iliac artery occlusion. 
These defects represent sites of placenta adherence that 
have arisen due to variations in the penetrating ability 
of the placental villi. This finding could potentially con tribute to a better understanding of the pathogenesis of 
placenta accreta and provide valuable insights into the 
successful conservation of the uterus.
The closure of muscle defects can be employed in cases 
of circumferential placental invasion (anterior, lateral, 
and posterior walls), either as a standalone technique or 
in combination with the myometrium resection method. 
Additionally, this approach can be applied to cases of 
upper uterine segment placental adherence. It enhances 
the likelihood of preserving the uterus, which is particu larly beneficial in countries with a high rate of Cesarean 
sections and in cases involving young women who are at 
an early age of marriage and childbirth, as illustrated in 
this case presentation.The only limitation was the absence of pathological 
examination for the uterus or the area of invasion due 
to nonresection of the affected tissue.
Conclusion
Ultrasound plays a crucial role in diagnosing placenta 
accreta and identifying any additional uterine abnor malities that may guide the planning of conservative 
treatment. Uterine septum represents a risk factor for 
placental adherence, as the placenta can indeed become 
adherent to it. Muscle defects may become apparent 
following placental separation and can often be effec tively managed through the use of running sutures, 
obviating the need for resection of the affected portion. 
Consequently, the likelihood of conserving the uterus 
increases, particularly when placenta increta is adher ent to the lateral and posterior walls, thereby averting 
the need for hysterectomy in these patients. However, 
it is essential to note that the technique for closure 
requires further research.
